body: Eh, ACK, but .. how is unrouteable traffic supposed to be grounds to terminate/shutdown your server??

Why do you want to communicate with such addresses?

NetRange:       240.0.0.0 - 255.255.255.255
CIDR:           240.0.0.0/4
NetName:        SPECIAL-IPV4-FUTURE-USE-IANA-RESERVED
NetHandle:      NET-240-0-0-0-0
Parent:          ()
NetType:        IANA Special Use
OriginAS:       
Organization:   Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA)
RegDate:        
Updated:        2013-08-30
Comment:        Addresses starting with 240 or a higher number have not been allocated and should not be used, apart from 255.255.255.255, which is used for "limited broadcast" on a local network.
Comment:        
Comment:        This block was reserved by the IETF, the organization that develops Internet protocols, in the Standard document and in RFC 1112.  The documents can be found at:
Comment:        http://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc1112
Ref:            http://whois.arin.net/rest/net/NET-240-0-0-0-0
ACK

@paveljanik As I said, I just used sipa's crawler. Maybe it can be extended to exclude certain problematic address ranges, or addresses that throw up with certain kinds of TCP errors. I told my provider that the same can happen with lots of other protocols, for example I could try to write an email to user@252.0.25.3 and I think common MTAs will try to connect to 252.0.25.3.

@schildbach a quick and dirty solution to make your server center happy would be this commit https://github.com/jonasschnelli/bitcoin-seeder/commit/4abf94b12baa62b1da60c0129c754f3f20171268

I had the same problem and hacked it down successfully with the patch above.
@jonasschnelli Please PR that?
I'd strongly prefer the DNS seed to be fixed instead of removed. Though if you insist I'll merge this.

Well the thing is Hetzner does not say in advance which IP addresses or ranges violate their policy. And they seemingly require a response time of just several hours (shorter than the average amount of sleep per night for sure). So I will not run the seeder again on this server.
@jonasschnelli I have more reports from Hetzner. Shall I all send them to you?
@schildbach: Yes. Please. Let's sort this out. Please forward the mails to dev@jonasschnelli.ch
@jonasschnelli I forwarded you all 4 reports I got.

I have updated the patch to avoid connecting to everything which is between 240.x.x.x and 255.255.255.255 in ipv4 space. This is now running on seed.bitcoin.jonasschnelli.ch. Let's see if Hetzner (datacenter provider) is happy with this. Will report back in some days (maybe @schildbach can do the same?).
@jonasschnelli I'll wait on your report (-:

Blocking >= 240.x.x.x wasn't sufficient (got a abuse report this night). 
Reverted back to the original hack PLUS block above >= 240.x.x.x.
I wonder if any of the IP addresses/ranges appear in some RFC document or specification as not to be used.
There is a paper: http://www.iana.org/assignments/ipv4-address-space/ipv4-address-space.xhtml. But following the ALLOCATED and LEGACY ranges will still end up in calling IP's which have no route.

Ah, @paveljanik already linked it above: http://whois.arin.net/rest/net/NET-240-0-0-0-0
Is this block excluded from bitcoind as well?

As example, the IP 1.0.1.4 was in the abuse report. But the seeder fond some valid bitcoin clients at 1.9.178.82:8333, 1.23.96.69:8333, etc. (many more).
Now how should we detect valid routes in 1.x.x.x range? Maybe just block 1.0.x.x but is there a definition what in the 1.x range is routable and what not?

The approach of hardcoding single IP addresses is not scalable. I tried to explain that to Hetzner as well, but I don't think the support guy understood.

I think we should identify blocks of IPs that are to be excluded by some form of specification (e.g. the 240.x.x.x block). These rules should then go into the seeder and bitcoind, because they are useful to anyone. 

Any other IPs reported by Hetzner we should ask them how we should know we should not connect them without trying in the first place. (I did that but didn't get a reply  maybe we need to be more people.)

Hmm... they just shut down my server (where the dns seed was running). Portscans are forbidden by the TOC. And i have to admit bitcoin-seeders ip collecting can be seen as a portscan. Any good ideas how to prevent/patch the seeder so that it won't be interpreted as portscan?

1) Would it be possible over TOR?
2) Maybe crawl in local home/office connection (no portscan rules) and upload the database to the seed server?
